page.title: 02LANDSCAPE & BUILDINGS contd.
page.content:
The most striking example is Glasshouses, with Smelthouses, New York and Low Laithe, although none of the mills is still used for its original purpose - the watercourses are still visible, however. On Guisecliffe and at various other points are the remains of the quarrying industry which provided good building stone up to the First World War. The housing is now almost all privately owned with some modern development, particularly in Glasshouses. Nearly all houses are built of the local millstone grit with flagstone roofs on the older buildings and blue slate on the more modern.
